title: Crowded Crosswalk: Urban Movement and Noise
caption: A crowded city intersection with many pedestrians crossing; tall buildings, taxis, and steam create a busy downtown atmosphere. Focus: clear description, inference, and TOEFL-style speaking, writing practice.

qa.q: What is the main action in the photo?
qa.a: I describe the main action using visible evidence and avoid guessing.
I explain indoor/outdoor clues and describe the environment without naming a specific city.

qa.q: What is the mood and why?
qa.a: I describe mood using facial expressions, posture, and lighting (if visible).

speakingPrompts: Describe the photo in 30 seconds using 3 visible details.
Give a 45-second response: description + likely situation + one broader idea.
Explain the mood and support your answer with two pieces of evidence.

reading.passage: Evidence-based description is a core academic skill. When describing a photo or a scene, strong speakers separate observation from interpretation. Observation focuses on what can be verified directly from the image, while interpretation uses cautious language to propose what might be happening.

questions.question: What is the best overall description of 'Crowded City Crosswalk'?
choices: A calm indoor meeting with formal presentations
People in a public setting engaged in an everyday activity
A private ceremony with an audience and a stage
A laboratory experiment with specialized equipment
questions.explanation: The scene title and context point to a public setting and routine activity rather than a formal ceremony, lab, or meeting.

questions.question: Which phrase is best for avoiding an unsupported guess?
questions.explanation: 'It appears that' is a hedging phrase that keeps your description evidence-based.

questions.question: Which connector best signals a contrast between two ideas?

listening.note: Read this as a script and practice note-taking.
listening.script: Today we will practice describing a photo. First, list what you can see. Second, explain what it might mean. Finally, connect it to a broader idea.

speakingTasks.prompt: Describe the scene in 'Crowded City Crosswalk'. What do you notice first?
Explain how the setting in 'Crowded City Crosswalk' affects the mood of the people.
Predict what might happen next in 'Crowded City Crosswalk' and give one reason.

writingTasks.prompt: Write a short description of the photo and summarize the main mood in 'Crowded City Crosswalk'.
Explain the relationship between the people and the setting in 'Crowded City Crosswalk'. Use at least two specific details.
writingTasks.sampleAnswer: In 'Crowded City Crosswalk', the setting provides clear context for the people’s actions. Overall, the scene feels purposeful because the subjects seem engaged and oriented toward a shared goal. For example, their body language suggests focus, and the environment appears to support that activity. As a result, the mood is more organized than casual, which indicates that the moment is part of a routine rather than a spontaneous event.

writingTasks.prompt: Some people prefer busy environments, while others prefer quiet ones. Using 'Crowded City Crosswalk' as inspiration, state your preference and support it with reasons.
writingTasks.sampleAnswer: I prefer quieter environments because they help me think clearly and work efficiently. In contrast, busy places can be distracting and make it harder to focus. For example, when I study in a calm space, I can organize my ideas and finish tasks faster. A possible explanation is that fewer interruptions reduce mental fatigue. Overall, choosing a quiet environment leads to better concentration and less stress, which improves my performance.

examTips: Start with a one-sentence overview before details.
Use location phrases (foreground/background) to organize your description.
Avoid guessing; hedge with 'it appears' or 'it is likely'.
Include 2–3 specific details (objects, actions, setting) to support ideas.
Use linking words (overall, in contrast, as a result) for coherence.
Speak steadily and manage time: plan 5 seconds, speak 40–45 seconds.

sceneNotes: Focus on what you can SEE (people, setting, actions).
- Simple: Mostly Present Continuous (am/is/are + V-ing) + basic 'There is/There are' for objects.
- Intermediate: Adds prepositional phrases (at/on/near), quantifiers (several/a few/a lot of), and 1 relative clause (who/that/where).
- Advanced: Adds inference language (probably/likely/might), contrast/linkers (while/whereas/in addition), and optional passive voice when relevant.
Add 1–2 inferences (why they are there, how they feel).
Use at least 2 collocations in your speaking/writing.

proDescriptions.label: TOEFL Speaking (45–60s)
proDescriptions.text: In this photo, a large crowd crosses a wide intersection in the center of a modern city. Yellow taxis wait behind the crosswalk line, and steam rises from a street vent, adding to the busy atmosphere Overall, the mood feels life and realistic.

proDescriptions.label: Academic Description
proDescriptions.text: The image portrays a crowded city crosswalk with many pedestrians, yellow taxis waiting, steam rising. Visual elements such as lighting, posture, and setting provide contextual cues that support an interpretation of mood and purpose. The composition balances foreground action with background environment to communicate a clear everyday scenario.

proDescriptions.label: Narrative Style
proDescriptions.text: The moment feels frozen in time: A large crowd crosses a wide intersection in the center of a modern city. Small details—light, movement, and expressions—turn an ordinary scene into a memorable snapshot.

sceneDescription: A large crowd crosses a wide intersection in the center of a modern city. Yellow taxis wait behind the crosswalk line, and steam rises from a street vent, adding to the busy atmosphere. Bright signs and tall buildings emphasize the fast pace of urban life.

scenario.en: Many pedestrians (mixed genders and ages) are in Downtown intersection, right in the middle of a real-life moment. They are crossing the street; walking in different directions. A large crowd crosses a wide intersection while taxis wait behind the line. There are Crosswalk, Traffic lights, Taxis/cars, Steam/vent around them, and the setting feels busy, fast-paced, urban energy. Their clothing, like Mixed urban clothing (jackets, shirts, backpacks), matches the situation and the environment.

scenarios.title: A memory
scenarios.en: Last weekend, I found myself in Downtown intersection. A large crowd crosses a wide intersection while taxis wait behind the line. At first, I noticed Crosswalk, Traffic lights, Taxis/cars and the way people were crossing the street. Then I looked closer: their clothing (Mixed urban clothing (jackets, shirts, backpacks)) and their expressions made the scene feel busy, fast-paced, urban energy. After that, something small happened that changed the mood, and we had to respond quickly. In the end, we solved it, and the moment became a story I still remember.
scenarios.fa: آخرِ هفته‌ی قبل Downtown intersection بودم. A large crowd crosses a wide intersection while taxis wait behind the line. اول Crosswalk، Traffic lights و Taxis/cars را دیدم و اینکه آدم‌ها چطور Crossing the street. بعد دقیق‌تر نگاه کردم: لباس‌ها (Mixed urban clothing (jackets, shirts, backpacks)) و حالت چهره‌ها باعث شد فضا Busy، Fast-paced و Urban energy به نظر برسد. بعدش یک اتفاق کوچک افتاد که حال‌وهوا را عوض کرد و مجبور شدیم سریع واکنش نشان بدهیم. آخرش حلش کردیم و همان لحظه تبدیل شد به خاطره‌ای که هنوز یادم می‌ماند.

grammarUsed.en: Past simple with time marker (last weekend) and sequencing (at first/then/after that/in the end).
grammarUsed.fa: گذشته ساده با قید زمان و ترتیب رخدادها (اول/بعد/بعدش/آخرش).

en.tense: Past Simple (V2) to tell a short memory, plus sequencing words (first/then/finally).
sentenceStructure: Time markers: yesterday / last week / a few minutes ago.
howToBuild: Start with a time phrase: Yesterday, Last weekend, A few minutes ago…
Change the main action into past simple (reviewed, chose, played…).
Use sequencing words to make a clear story: first, then, after that, finally.
End with a result or feeling: Everyone felt… / It turned out…
examples: Yesterday, they crossed the street.
Then, they checked Crosswalk and continued.
Finally, they felt Busy about the outcome.

fa.tense: گذشته ساده (Past Simple) برای تعریف یک خاطره کوتاه، همراه با کلمات ترتیب‌دهنده (first/then/finally).
sentenceStructure: عبارات زمانی: yesterday / last week / a few minutes ago
howToBuild: با یک عبارت زمانی شروع کن: Yesterday, Last weekend, A few minutes ago…
فعل اصلی را به گذشته ساده تبدیل کن (reviewed, chose, played…).
از کلمات ترتیب‌دهنده استفاده کن: first, then, after that, finally.
با نتیجه یا حس تمام کن: Everyone felt… / It turned out…
examples: دیروز، They crossed the street.
بعد، They Crosswalk را بررسی کرد و ادامه داد.
در نهایت، آن‌ها درباره نتیجه Busy بودند.

scenarios.title: Reflection
scenarios.en: Over the past few months, I have started paying attention to scenes like this. I have noticed that details such as Crosswalk, Traffic lights, Taxis/cars, Steam/vent are not background; they guide the story. I have also learned how actions like walking in different directions can signal feelings such as busy, fast-paced, urban energy. Since then, I have taken more time to observe before I speak, and my descriptions have become clearer and more specific.
scenarios.fa: در چند ماه گذشته شروع کرده‌ام به صحنه‌هایی مثل این بیشتر دقت کنم. متوجه شده‌ام جزئیاتی مثل Crosswalk، Traffic lights، Taxis/cars و Steam/vent فقط «پس‌زمینه» نیستند؛ آن‌ها مسیر داستان را تعیین می‌کنند. همچنین یاد گرفته‌ام کارهایی مثل Walking in different directions چطور می‌تواند احساساتی مثل Busy، Fast-paced و Urban energy را نشان بدهد. از آن زمان بیشتر قبل از حرف زدن مشاهده می‌کنم و توصیف‌هایم واضح‌تر و دقیق‌تر شده است.

grammarUsed.en: Present perfect to connect past learning to the present, plus since/over the past to frame experience.
grammarUsed.fa: حال کامل برای وصل کردن یادگیری گذشته به حال، همراه با «در چند ماه گذشته/از آن زمان».

en.tense: Present Perfect (have/has + past participle) to connect past experience to the present; use since/for/already/yet.
howToBuild: Say what has happened up to now (experience/result).
Use since (a starting point) or for (a duration).
Add a contrast or reflection: however, although, even though.
Finish with what they are doing now (present continuous) if needed.
examples: They have already handled similar situations before.
They have learned to stay Busy in Downtown intersection.
Although it looks routine, the details have mattered.

fa.tense: حال کامل (have/has + شکل سوم فعل) برای ربط دادن گذشته به حال؛ همراه با since/for/already/yet.
howToBuild: بگو تا همین الآن چه تجربه/نتیجه‌ای اتفاق افتاده.
از since (نقطه شروع) یا for (مدت زمان) استفاده کن.
یک جمله‌ی بازتاب/تضاد اضافه کن: however, although, even though.
اگر لازم شد با یک جمله حال استمراری وضعیت الآن را بگو.
examples: They قبلاً موقعیت‌های مشابهی را تجربه کرده است.
They یاد گرفته است در Downtown intersection Busy بماند.
اگرچه کار روتین به نظر می‌رسد، جزئیات مهم بوده‌اند.

scenarios.title: A challenge
scenarios.en: If we were to replay this moment in Downtown intersection, one small change could create a big problem. If Crosswalk, Traffic lights had been missing or damaged, we would have had to improvise. Someone might have said, “We should slow down and check,” and another person could have replied that we were running out of time. In a situation like this, we should prioritize safety and clarity, even if it means changing the plan. If I had ignored those details, I might have misunderstood the whole scene.
scenarios.fa: اگر قرار بود این لحظه در Downtown intersection دوباره تکرار شود، یک تغییر کوچک می‌توانست یک مشکل بزرگ بسازد. اگر Crosswalk و Traffic lights نبود یا آسیب دیده بود، مجبور می‌شدیم بداهه تصمیم بگیریم. ممکن بود کسی بگوید «باید آهسته‌تر برویم و بررسی کنیم» و نفر دیگری جواب بدهد که وقت کم داریم. در چنین موقعیتی بهتر است ایمنی و شفافیت را در اولویت بگذاریم، حتی اگر مجبور شویم برنامه را تغییر بدهیم. اگر آن جزئیات را نادیده می‌گرفتم، شاید کل صحنه را اشتباه می‌فهمیدم.

grammarUsed.en: Conditionals for hypotheticals, modals for advice/possibility, and short reported speech (might have said/could have replied).
grammarUsed.fa: شرطی‌ها برای موقعیت فرضی، افعال کمکی برای امکان/پیشنهاد، و نقل‌قول غیرمستقیم برای بازگویی گفت‌وگو.

en.tense: Mixed grammar for higher-level storytelling: conditionals, modals (might/must), and reported speech.
sentenceStructure: Second conditional: If + past simple, would + base verb.
Third conditional: If + had + V3, would have + V3.
Modals of deduction: might/must/can't + base verb.
Reported speech: He said (that) … / She asked if …
howToBuild: Describe the challenge and add a hypothetical solution (If…, would…).
Use modals to infer causes from the photo (They might…, It must…).
Add reported speech for realism: Someone said that…
Finish with a consequence or lesson learned.
examples: If they had checked Crosswalk earlier, they would have avoided a mistake.
They might be under pressure, but they must stay Busy.
The supervisor said that every detail mattered.

fa.tense: گرامر ترکیبی سطح بالا: شرطی‌ها، افعال کمکی (might/must) و نقل قول غیرمستقیم (reported speech).
sentenceStructure: شرطی نوع دوم: If + past simple, would + فعل ساده.
شرطی نوع سوم: If + had + V3, would have + V3.
نقل قول غیرمستقیم: He said (that)… / She asked if…
howToBuild: چالش را بگو و یک راه‌حل فرضی اضافه کن (If…, would…).
با مدال‌ها درباره علت‌ها حدس بزن (might/must).
برای واقعی‌تر شدن از reported speech استفاده کن.
در پایان نتیجه یا درسِ داستان را بگو.
examples: اگر They زودتر Crosswalk را چک کرده بود، اشتباه را جلوگیری می‌کرد.
ممکن است تحت فشار باشند، اما باید Busy بمانند.
سرپرست گفت که هر جزئیاتی مهم است.
